column4: Greetings all, my seamonkey application keeps crashing. Here is the terminal output when it occurs: http://pastebin.com/8C6Bv1xL
What does 'buffer overflow' mean?
It means a buffer that has so much stuff in it that stuff gets lost cause the buffer is not large enough to hold it all
This is attributed to my Seamonkey application
Seamonkey is a browser?
Correct

I don't know what buffer it is referring to (or what buffers there are).  Usually buffers are used to accept packets on the network card.  If too many packets are recieved (before they can be processed) the buffer will overflow with packets and they'll be lost.  This is what happens in a DDOS attack
It is definitely a software issue.  Buffers exist only in software
Have you done a memtest recently?  If not then you can't claim you're rigorous about checking hardware
thanks, I think a solution is to build from source and launch the application manuallyu
Yes I do regularly
Are you overclocking?
No
You want to compile every program that is doing this from source?

Seamonkey is a modest browser application, however I store a lot of e-mails. As for compiling from source, it seems to be the only way to get the program I need to work. Alternately, I can just use another distro. For instance, this issue never occurs in Slackware
Sounds like you have the answers to your own questions.
No, the buffer memory thing is still an issue I have not resolved with Ubuntu\
I have no idea what is causing the problem.  I can only suggest test to start doing that are very generic like changing the kernel
There is an idea
perhaps it's a good one
It sounds about right
good luck
Thanks for your help]
sure
